items.title: School security industry may be booming, but little is helping to stop shootings
Inside HP’s AI bet to rebuild itself for the ‘work intelligence’ age
items.summary:
- HP is redefining itself as a work‑intelligence platform, unifying devices, software, services and cloud under a platform-led model to boost recurring revenue.
- AI PCs with on‑device neural processing units deliver faster, private inference and embed AI across print, docs, meetings and offline workflows.
- Hybrid compute, blending local AI with cloud scale, and DXP/lifecycle services signal a shift from device revenue to software and services.

items.title: Exploring a new city? Grab these 3 free, under-the-radar apps first
My Private, Free AI Setup
Apple’s 3 biggest wins and 3 greatest failures of 2025
items.summary:
- iPhone 17 lineup exceeded sales expectations, boosting Apple stock amid tariff fears as demand rose in the US and China, with upgrades to display, camera, and longer battery life.
- iPhone 17 Pro/Pro Max feature a new unibody design and up to 39 hours of battery life, strengthening premium positioning.
- Liquid Glass debuts as iOS 26’s design language, delivering a radical visual overhaul—the first major iOS redesign since 2013.

items.title: This brilliant free website makes Wikipedia infinitely better
items.summary:
- Wikiboard visualizes your Wikipedia browsing as a mind map, showing connections as you move between articles.
- It adds a cork-board style view of related topics you've encountered so you can jump into exploration immediately.
- The idea was shared as a tip in The Intelligence's free Cool Tools newsletter.

items.title: Meet Google Maps’s new intelligent planning companion
items.summary:
- Roadtrippers is described as a virtual companion that augments standard navigation (Google Maps, Waze, Apple Maps) with features to make road trips more entertaining and enjoyable.
- It's pitched for holiday travel planning or extended drives, offering on-route entertainment alongside your usual navigation.
- The tip originated in The Intelligence’s Cool Tools newsletter.

items.title: Sequoia’s Shaun Maguire accused an innocent Palestinian of being the Brown shooter. Then he doubled down
items.summary:
- Authorities identified Claudio Manuel Neves Valente as Brown University’s December 13 shooter and tied MIT professor Nuno Loureiro’s death to separate causes, countering online conspiracies promoted by Maguire.
- Maguire had publicly claimed a Palestinian Brown student was the shooter and speculated Loureiro’s death was tied to Jewish identity; Brown scrubbed the student’s online presence as a safety step.
- The piece notes Maguire’s history of inflammatory posts toward Muslims and pro-Palestine activists and mentions an open letter urging Sequoia to fire him; Sequoia did not comment.

items.title: YouTube creator’s finance livestream mysteriously appears on White House website
items.summary: - An unexpected livestream by YouTube creator Matt Farley (RealMattMoney) appeared for at least eight minutes on whitehouse.gov/live. - The White House said it is aware and investigating whether the incident was a hack or an inadvertent link. - Farley said he had no idea his stream would be publicly streamed by a government site, with the context tied to a longer personal-finance livestream.

items.title: Yes, the Trump administration is likely to buy more equity in more private companies in 2026
items.summary:
- The US government bought minority stakes in several private firms in 2025 and signals ongoing equity investments under Trump, framed as industrial policy.
- Advocates say it aligns the executive branch with vital industries, rebuilds supply chains, and reduces China exposure; critics warn of government venture-capital risks.
- The biggest stake is 9.9% in Intel, funded by $8.9B CHIPS Act money; debate continues on expanding equity to defense contractors and other crises-era precedents.

items.title: Instacart settles with FTC for $60 million over alleged false advertising
TikTok signs a deal forming a new U.S. unit including investors Oracle and Silver Lake
How AI made me more (and less) productive in 2025
Retro, a photo-sharing app for friends, lets you ‘time-travel’ through your camera roll
AI’s butterfly effect: The danger of cascade failures
Why brands are going unhinged on TikTok (and winning big)
Tin Can has reinvented the house phone for today’s families
Is ‘artificial general intelligence’ an illusion? Yann LeCun thinks so
items.summary:
- Yann LeCun argues AGI is a myth and humans aren’t true generalists; he favors focusing on narrow, reliable AI tasks.
- He criticizes the industry’s obsession with AGI and urges solving real-world problems to create value and reduce suffering.
- The debate weighs human vs machine limits in chess and math, questioning AGI as a practical target.

items.title: 6 ways to uplug from the online world this holiday season
items.summary:
- Use Focus modes and Screen Time to silence notifications and cap apps (e.g., Instagram at 20 minutes); enable grayscale; delete addictive apps if needed.
- Move outdoors away from Wi‑Fi to reset—forest bathing, cold-weather mittens; Touch Grass (iOS) forces outdoor breaks; if unavailable, touch snow or sand.
- Handwrite notes or letters and read long-form books for better learning, focus, and empathy; check year‑end book lists for ideas.

items.title: Indie bookstores are making a shocking, triumphant comeback
items.summary:
- Indie bookstores rose 70% in five years and added 422 outlets in 2025; Harvard Business School's Ryan Raffaelli calls it a resilience- and community-driven revival.
- Independents lean into in-store strengths: hundreds of events and curated selections that algorithms can’t replicate.
- Staff are deeply connected to current literary culture, a community Amazon hasn’t duplicated, despite pursuing physical stores.

items.title: These sites and apps will help you assemble the perfect holiday reading list
items.summary:
- Whichbook relies on human readers to classify mood, violence, sexual content, main characters and length, with adjustable sliders for personalized matches.
- It offers a low-pressure discovery experience, avoids pushing bestsellers, and can surface titles by region via an interactive map.
- The piece situates Whichbook within a broader recs ecosystem (BookTok, Reddit, Goodreads, The Storygraph, Fable) and notes no system is perfect, per Tertulia's Sebastian Cwilich.

items.title: Deepfakes are no longer just a disinformation problem. They are your next supply chain risk
items.summary:
- Deepfakes have evolved from curiosity to systemic corporate risk, capable of disrupting supply chains, financial workflows, and executive decisions.
- The Arup incident (Feb 2025) shows attackers impersonating senior leaders to steal millions, exposing identity-verification gaps.
- Defenses must go beyond traditional cybersecurity to address trusted-channel deception and executive-impersonation resilience.

items.title: The Warner Bros.-Netflix merger could doom Hollywood film workers
items.summary:
- Since strikes, Hollywood entered a leaner era with lower production and many workers not returning, threatening jobs and wages as the Netflix-WBD bid raises antitrust concerns.
- Unions warn the merger could reduce jobs, suppress wages, erode conditions, and shrink content diversity; groups urge protections and a boost to production for workers.
- Proponents say the deal could spur innovation and growth, but analysts cite financing and consolidation risks; below-the-line workers would bear much of the impact.

items.title: Here’s how much you racked up on Uber Eats in 2025
items.summary:
- YOUBER aggregates Uber and Uber Eats activity into a year-in-review with trips, orders, and spending in one stat card.
- It flags frequent restaurants and top-percent spenders, with personalized messages; example: a $24,000 delivery total (the real figure is less brutal than the parody).
- US-only feature in-app banner, mirroring year-in-review trends from Spotify/YouTube and inspired by the late-2023 SNL sketch.
